byline.contributor: Ben Fenwick reported from Oklahoma City, and Alan Schwarz from New York. Katie Rogers contributed reporting from New York.
byline.original: By BEN FENWICK and ALAN SCHWARZ

abstract: Victim Jannie Ligons speaks at news conference following conviction of former Oklahoma City Police Officer Daniel Holtzclaw, who is found guilty of 18 counts of rape and other charges involving attacks on 13 black women; her story had helped prompt investigation that led to case against Holtzclaw; jury recommends Holtzclaw receive 263 years in prison, and his sentencing is scheduled for January 2016.
lead_paragraph: Two of Daniel Holtzclaw’s victims described their horror over the assaults, as the verdict was met with praise for the jury but outrage with a system that failed to protect poor black women.

headline.main: In Rape Case of Oklahoma Officer, Victims Hope Conviction Will Aid Cause
headline.print_headline: In Rape Case, Hoping a Verdict Will Aid a Cause
